thread.title: UPDATE 1-U.S. SEC meted out $4.2 bln in sanctions in 2015 fiscal year
thread.title_full: UPDATE 1-U.S. SEC meted out $4.2 bln in sanctions in 2015 fiscal year | Reuters

author: Reuters
title: UPDATE 1-U.S. SEC meted out $4.2 bln in sanctions in 2015 fiscal year
text:
(Adds details about a "dark pool" case and a study about SEC process for computing enforcement results, paragraphs 4-8)
By Suzanne Barlyn
Oct 22 (Reuters) - The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission meted out $4.2 billion in sanctions against wrongdoers subject to enforcement actions during its 2015 fiscal year, the agency said on Thursday.
The agency, in an annual synopsis of its enforcement efforts, also said that it had filed 807 cases during the period, which ended on Sept. 30.
While the number of cases was higher than the 705 the SEC filed during its 2014 fiscal year, sanctions were roughly even with the $4.16 billion the SEC imposed during that time.
This year included numerous first-of-their-kind cases, the SEC said. They included, for example, a case against a UBS AG unit, which agreed to pay more than $14.4 million to settle charges over regulatory failures in its private U.S. trading platform, known as a "dark pool," that gave some of customers an advantage over others.
The UBS unit neither admitted nor denied the SEC's allegations.
The SEC's annual enforcement results came under scrutiny in September when a draft study by an Emory University law professor of 15 years of data critiqued the SEC's metrics for computing its annual enforcement statistics as "deeply flawed."
Law professor Urska Velikonja found that a host of problems, including double-counting cases, has enabled the SEC to "mask the fact that core enforcement has remained steady since 2002." The study is slated to be published in the Cornell Law Review.
SEC Enforcement Director Andrew Ceresney said at the time that agency disagrees with a number of Velikonja's observations. (Reporting by Suzanne Barlyn; Editing by Chizu Nomiyama and David Gregorio)
